ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The first part of the class was just an overview of the military campaigns in ww1 during the Middle East. The second part delves deeper into the nature of the political projects during the aftermath of WW1.

This course taught me the importance of reimagining historical givens (i.e. timelines, maps, etc.) As a descendent of Armenian Genocide survivors, this course brought me closer to my family's past while providing me with useful knowledge of an incredibly complex region.

This class was such a wonderful deep dive into WW1, opening up the timeline and the geographical area from which we usually study this conflict. Professor Wyrtzen was incredibly knowledgeable on the subject and very open to hearing students ideas and encouraging them to push their ideas further.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof. Wyrtzen is great in class, he makes a point to think with us and take us into consideration. It's really nice to follow Prof. Wyrtzen through his thinking.
This course is well organized and the assignments found the perfect balance of challenge and flexibility to students' interests. I have no suggestions.

Strengths - goes into very specific detail on events in the Middle East
Weaknesses - scope and depth of this course can get confusing. Goes too into depth about too many topics it seems. Readings can be long and pedantic.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but prepare to be in the dark about the assignments until like a week before. Also, don't expect feedback until ... actually just don't expect feedback.

I would--even if he or she does not have a special interest in Middle East history. The course is a valuable lesson in how history is remembered and reshaped by dominant populations. The assignments compliment this lesson by pushing students to find their own examples within the scope of the class.
Yes. Be ready for a pretty decent amount of reading but as long as you engage with it some and write a thoughtful response youll be smooth sailing in this class
Not really. The topic is inherently interesting however this class did not feel too exciting.

extras.title: HIST 324J 01/MMES 322 01/SOCY 320 01 - WWI and the Middle East
